See comments about remaining cython/pickle issues.

You're absolutely right that in its current form having two separate classes accomplishes nothing.  The idea is that `_BaseOffset` should be a `cdef class`, while `BaseOffset` should be python class.  (`__rfoo__` methods do not play nicely with cython classes).
ok that is fine.

I would probably leave this as a class for the moment. I am not convinced this actually needs to be a full c-extension class (e.g. its not like we are inheriting from a python c-class here). I don't see the benefit and it has added complexity.

The main reason is to achieve immutability.  That's the big roadblock between us and making `__eq__`, `__ne__`, `__hash__` performance not-awful.  (There's an issue somewhere about "scalar types immutable" or something like that)

@@ -1,1 +307,311 @@    def __init__(self, n=1, normalize=False):
        n = self._validate_n(n)

comments.body: what is _cache for?
If we don't create this explicitly in `__init__` then `@cache_readonly` lookups will try to create it, which will raise.
can you put this on the class? (or is that really weird)?

```
pd.DateOffset._cache = {}
off = pd.DateOffset(n=1)
hour = pd.offsets.BusinessHour(n=2)

>>> off._cache is hour._cache
True
```
right so we can't use the ``@cache_readonly`` decorator here? (or is that what you are doing by pre-emptively setting the cache)?

`cache_readonly.__get__` checks for a `_cache` attribute and creates one if it does not exist.  Creating it in `__init__` ensures that one exists, so a new one does not have to be created (since attempting to do so would raise)
i.e. this is necessary in order to retain the existing usages of `cache_readonly` on `DateOffset` subclasses.
ok makes sense

Thx
Sorry copied it around and then missed this :(

Changing from `n=self.n` to `n=1` does not have any effect on the functionality. I just thought having n=1 is 1) more consistent with `MonthBegin(n=1)` and `MonthEnd(n=1)` below; and 2) slightly more indicative of the role of `CustomBusinessDay`, which is simply to apply a 1-day rollforward/rollback.
can you not just pass kwds & offset here?

Likely I didn't fully understanding your suggestion here. Do you by any chance mean passing `**self.kwds` as before? So the idea here is that if _self.offset is not timedelta(0)_, then we always use `CustomBusinessDay(n=1, normalize=False, offset=timedelta(0), ...)` to roll to a business day first, and then separately add the self.offset afterwards. 

The reason is that `.rollforward` (and `.rollback`) only calls `.apply` when if `.is_on_offset(dt)` returns `False` (code [here](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/master/pandas/_libs/tslibs/offsets.pyx#L590-L616) and [here](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/master/pandas/_libs/tslibs/offsets.pyx#L3227-L3255)), which I think can be illustrated well with the following example:

```python
In[33]: import pandas as pd
   ...: print(pd.__version__)
1.3.0.dev0+1628.g32ce31be89
In[34]: cbday_plus_5d = pd.offsets.CustomBusinessDay(n=1, offset=timedelta(days=5))
   ...: # define a CBDay with an extra offset of 5 days
In[35]: print(cbday_plus_5d.rollforward(pd.Timestamp('2021-05-02')))  # expected 2021-05-08
   ...: # 2021-05-02 not a business day, so 'rollforward' makes it 2021-05-03 + extra 5 days
2021-05-08 00:00:00
In[36]: print(cbday_plus_5d.rollforward(pd.Timestamp('2021-05-03')))  # expected 2021-05-08
   ...: # 2021-05-03 is ALREADY a business day, so it doesn't get rolled at all.
2021-05-03 00:00:00
```

So instead, we enforce `offset=timedelta(0)` while constructing `CustomBusinessDay` as follows, which is why I am first modifying the 'offset' parameter:

```python
In[42]: cbday_no_offset = pd.offsets.CustomBusinessDay(n=1, offset=timedelta(0))
In[43]: print(cbday_no_offset.rollforward(pd.Timestamp('2021-05-03')) + timedelta(days=5))  # expected 2021-05-08
2021-05-08 00:00:00
```

Please let me know if I completely missed your question. Would love to hear your thoughts. Thanks!

I think what jreback is suggesting is:

```
if self.offset:
    cbday_kwds = self.kwds.copy()
    cbday_kwds['offset'] = timedelta(0)
else:
    cbday_kwds = self.kwds
```

should instead just be:

```
cbday_kwds = self.kwds.copy()
cbday_kwds['offset'] = timedelta(0)
```

Ah, I see. I added the check here to prevent unnecessary data copying, because I am guessing `offset=timedelta(0)` is the more common use case and works as expected. What do you think? Definitely happy to change it accordingly.

Bumping this thread. Let me know what you think about 1) always making a new copy `cbday_kwds = self.kwds.copy()` vs. 2) only copying when `self.offset` is not `timedelta(0)`. I will make changes accordingly. :)

As a refresher for your convenience, the idea is that we want to first use `CustomBusinessDay(n=1, normalize=False, offset=timedelta(0), ...)` (instead of any non-zero offset) to roll to a business day first, and then separately apply the `self.offset` afterwards in `.apply`.
im fine with this either way
